title-group.article-title: The triple role of values in culturally adapted leadership styles

contrib-group.aff: NHH- Norwegian School of Economics, Norway

author-notes.corresp: Ghulam Mustafa, Department of Strategy and Management, NHH-Norwegian School of Economics, Bergen, Norway. Email: ghulam.mustafa@nhh.no

abstract.p: Prior research has established that culturally adapted leadership is associated with positive outcomes for organizations as well as for leaders and followers. However, the adaptation of leadership styles to national culture is under pressure mainly due to the professionalization of leadership grounded in a formal knowledge base that is predominantly derived from research in Anglo-American cultural settings and performed by Anglo-American leadership researchers. In this paper, we argue that the forces leading to a drift away from cultural adaptation are partly counteracted by three mechanisms tying leaders to the cultural context in which they operate. This theoretical perspective allows us to understand better observed leadership in a national setting as equilibrium between cultural forces and institutional forces grounded in culturally biased formal research and leadership education based on this research. To illustrate the added value of this perspective, we develop some specific propositions concerning the three mechanisms and their relative strengths under a variety of cultural conditions.

body.p: The main purpose of this paper is to explore three mechanisms by which cultural values may lead to the cultural adaptation of leadership. While most normative models for effective leadership are based on Anglo-American data and thinking, much leadership is obviously enacted in multicultural settings or cultures that differ from the Anglo-American in important respects (Hofstede, 1980; House et al., 2004).

Comparative research in cross-national settings strongly indicate that follower responses to specific leadership styles or facets are highly dependent on follower1 values, which in turn are partly reflected by their national cultural backgrounds (Den Hartog et al., 1999). Leaders2 who behave consistently with important follower values elicit responses such as positive emotions and thoughts, and supportive and motivated behaviours such as innovation, knowledge sharing and generally higher levels of effort (Brown and Trevino, 2009; Fiebig and Kramer, 1998; Foss et al., 2009). Leaders whose behaviours are in conflict with important follower values elicit negative emotions, sometimes characterized as ‘white hot’, negative thoughts and attitudes, such as intentions to leave the organization, and behaviours such as resistance, sabotage, unwanted turnover, and a generally lower level of work effort (Gooty et al., 2010).

This provides a strong argument for adaptation of leadership style to follower cultural values. However, culturally adapted leadership, which may be seen as a natural form of leadership in a national setting, is under pressure. Mainstream textbooks used for educating a new generation of leaders are predominantly transferring Anglo-American values and implicitly creating norms for good leadership which may be alien to the cultural setting and possibly lead to value destruction rather than value creation (Chin, 2010). Second, sometimes leaders seek advice from professional management consultants in order to improve their leadership work. Management consultants, however, rely on the same body of thought, i.e. Anglo-American leadership theory, and provide increased impetus away from cultural adaptation (Gerson, 2005). Third, ownership is increasingly globalized. This may lead to the composition of culturally incompetent boards and provide subtle incentives to move leadership away from the cultural setting in which it is performed (Tuselmann et al., 2002). Performance implications of such shifts in leadership are poorly understood, and empirical research on these issues is badly needed (Child and Kieser, 1979).

We argue that these forces are partly counteracted by three mechanisms that may protect leaders from movement away from culturally adapted styles. First, leaders are often members of the culture in which they lead. This implies that personal values of leaders are congruent with follower values. As a person’s value system exerts a strong influence on the person’s thinking and behaving, local leaders are better positioned to enact culturally adapted leadership. Second, sophisticated leaders understand that their capacity to create value is mediated by positive rather than negative responses to their behaviours (including decision-making and process design). Hence leaders, regardless of their personal value systems, will seek to lead in a way that is consistent with their followers’ value systems. Third, organizational life is increasingly observed and scrutinized by the general public. For example, organizations that operate in conflict with public opinion is likely to be sanctioned by customers, regulators, and possibly financial institutions. Public opinion about organizations’ behaviour is partly a reflection of shared cultural values. Hence, shared cultural values function as a framework within which leaders make their choices, regardless of their or their followers’ values.

The interrelationship between national culture and leadership behaviours is at the very core of research on cross-cultural leadership. Hence, much knowledge has been accumulated on how leaders adapt to the aspects of national culture and the effects of (non) adaptation (e.g. Adler, 1997; Black and Porter, 1991; Elenkov and Manev, 2005; Neelankavil et al., 2000; Shahin and Right, 2004). However, up to this point, a coherent account of the mechanisms by which leaders are influenced by national culture has not been fully explicated. This is an important area for theory development, because better understanding of these mechanisms is required for designing interventions in cases where cultural adaptation is deemed crucial for organizational goal achievement as well as leader and employee wellbeing (e.g. Agarwal et al., 1999; Gao and Gudykunst, 1990; Newman and Nollen, 1996).

In this paper, we present three potential mechanisms by which national culture may influence leadership styles. From a micro-level perspective, we propose that leaders’ personal values, being culturally patterned, produce correspondence between their leadership styles and cultural values. From a meso-level perspective, we suggest that subordinates of the same cultural background form value communities and show similar responses to different leadership behaviours. Leaders can explore subordinates’ cultural values by transforming their experiences of subordinates’ reactions and use this knowledge as a foundation for exhibiting culturally adapted behaviours. From a macro-level perspective, we argue that societal values have certain legitimating effects on organizations in a particular national setting, which influence organizational phenomena and serve to limit the behaviours of leaders in organizations. We also attempt to present an analysis of the potential link between national culture and the strength of each proposed mechanism under different cultural settings.

sec.title: Culture and leadership interface: A brief review of existing literature
sec.p: The ongoing debate between researchers as to whether leadership is governed by universal principles or culture-dependent has led to the development of two schools of thought, i.e. a realist and a relativist school. Those who support the realist approach (e.g. Bass, 1985; Bolman and Deal, 1991; Kouzes and Posner, 1988) contend that, since all leaders perform similar functions, the core leadership processes should be similar, regardless of cultural differences. The realist researchers are often interested in testing US-based leadership theories and models in non-American societies to see if they are generalizable to other cultures beyond the American context. The other school of thought, which might be labelled as relativist, supports the idea of cultural differences in leadership behaviours and leadership preferences (e.g. Dorfman and Howell, 1988; Hofstede, 1980, 1984; House et al., 2004; Triandis, 1993). This stream of research results from a realization that the uncritical adaptation of management models and techniques evolved in the context of Anglo-American cultural values may not be effective in other socio-cultural environments. Researchers from this school of thought contend that all leadership behaviours may not be universally effective, rather effectiveness of such behaviours is closely associated with the national culture where leadership is enacted. This suggests that leadership styles that are linked to leader effectiveness in one country may not be equally efficacious in other national settings. The basic logic for this position is that, because national societies are different in terms of their cultural values, organizations are influenced in their strategies and practices by the cultural values of the national society to which they belong (Hofstede, 1980; House et al., 2004; Schwartz, 1994). Importantly, followers’ responses to a given leadership behaviour may be strongly dependent on their cultural values (e.g. Yan and Hunt, 2005).

Many cross-cultural studies (e.g. Den Hartog et al., 1999; Offermann and Hellmann,1997; Pasa et al., 2001; Ralston et al., 1997) lend credence to the latter approach by reporting differences among countries with regard to perceptions of effective leadership and use of specific leadership behaviours. Together, these studies suggest that leadership effectiveness is a function of culture and that managers need to know what constitutes effective leadership in different cultural settings. Managers who have a good cultural awareness and perform behaviours that conform to the values of a particular national culture are likely to be more effective (Fu and Yukl, 2000). The bulk of work on the culture–leadership link, however, has focused on culture-specific perceptions and patterns of leadership behaviour without specifying the mechanisms by which the relationships are produced.

Nonetheless, there are a few studies (Dickson et al., 2004; Fu and Yukl, 2000; Hanges et al., 2000; House et al., 1997; Lord and Maher, 1991), which suggest a number of ways by means of which national culture may influence leadership behaviours. Given these studies, the need to present a holistic depiction of the processes by which national culture influences leadership styles still remains there. These studies are either follower-focused or organization-centric in their approach to studying the influence of culture on leadership behaviour and attributes. The present study is unique in the sense that it offers a comprehensive explication regarding the influence of national culture on leadership by clarifying processes that are leader, follower and organization-centric. It may have implications for leadership in local organizations, leaders in foreign subsidiaries and in organizations with culturally diverse workforces. The study attempts to contribute to the existing literature by addressing the following questions: what are the mechanisms by which cultural values lead to cultural adaptation of leadership styles; and how do cultural differences influence the strength of each potential mechanism?

Figure 1 provides an overview of the proposed conceptual framework where leader personal values, follower values and societal values link national culture through different adaptation processes to leadership in organizations, which in turn influence leadership styles. The arc-like structure which connects three lines in this figure, represents interaction among the mechanisms. In the figure, differences in cultural values among national cultures are posited to impact the strength of proposed mechanisms.

sec.title: Leadership cultural adaptation and mechanisms of influence
sec.p: In our development of mechanisms leading to cultural adaptation, we draw on three different literatures: literature on cultural embeddedness (e.g. Hofstede, 1980, 1983), experiential learning theory (Kolb, 1984) and neo-institutional theory (Scott, 1995). The literature on cultural embeddedness posits that, once socialized in a society, people’s identity or sense of self is largely shaped by national culture, which may be characterized by a distinct set of values. In fact, a manager’s thinking is conditioned by views and assumptions characteristic of a national culture through formal and informal socialization (Hofstede, 1980, 1983), which may in turn be reflected in leader personal values (Kanungo and Jaeger, 1990). Reviewing and integrating this stream of literature, we propose that managers who belong to a particular national culture develop personal values that partially reflect the native national culture. Experiential learning theory (Kolb, 1984) posits that learning occurs through transformation of experiences. Drawing from ELT, we argue that managers through experiences of reactions may learn employee values. By reflecting upon such experiences leaders may develop ideas and concepts that act as guiding maps and over time produce correspondence between their behaviours and follower values. New institutional theory contends that institutional expectations influence features and characteristics of organizations operating in a particular cultural setting (DiMaggio and Powell, 1991; Scott, 1995). Drawing on neo-institutional theory, we argue that organizations comply with societal values and norms of acceptable behaviour to achieve legitimacy and societal approbation, which in turn influences the entire organizational phenomenon, including leadership.

sec.title: Personal values and leadership cultural adaptation: A value internalization perspective
sec.p: Every individual attaches meaning to the self through the concept of personal identity and tends to act in furtherance of his or her own goals and desires. Personal identity underscores a sense of individual autonomy rather than adopting a group’s perspective (Hewitt, 1997). This sense of distinctiveness is, however, not simply produced by the individual’s self-definition as a unique entity different from other members of the collectivity (Gecas, 1982), rather it is constituted by the individual’s value commitments (Hitlin, 2003). That is, people belonging to a social group may possess the same values, but the extent to which a particular value has been incorporated varies between individuals. Broadly speaking, personal values reflect the values of the collectivity, but ranking of specific values in terms of their importance is somewhat individualized (Rokeach, 1973). For instance, people may have both self-transcendent and self-enhancement values but differ with respect to the degree of priority placed on each of the values (Fu et al., 2010).

As a function of such interpersonal variance in the ranking of values, individuals tend to differ in their actions and behaviours that may be value consistent. Individual values thus serve as the basic constituents that may determine a person’s self construal or sense of personal identity. But an individual’s self-concept that he or she experiences as unique and distinct is socially patterned through his/her personal values (Hitlin, 2003). As argued by Hitlin (2003: 121), an individual’s personal values, which form his/her sense of uniqueness, keep the self connected with social structure as ‘values develop in social contexts and draw on culturally significant symbolic material’, and in their developmental process they are subject to social patterning and communication. Any attempt to grasp the notion of self-construal or individual identity without tracing its social link, therefore, neglects the fact that personal idiosyncrasies (Turner et al., 1987) are not easy to understand unless social definitions are used as a lens to observe and interpret them (Deaux, 1996).

This suggests that values that are seen as personally important are not only a product of individuals’ distinct make-up; rather, through socialization processes individuals tend to internalize socially desirable values, which may become part of the repertoire of one’s personal value preferences (Allport, 1955). This is apparent from the fact that some value commonality may be evidenced among members of each national society. Individuals in every society are exposed to the same institutional structures and governmental systems, which give rise to societal norms and practices that reflect some degree of cultural value similarity (Sagiv and Schwartz, 2007). Thus, people in some countries may be, on average, higher on a certain value type than people in other countries due to systematic differences in the cultural structure (e.g. Gatignon et al., 1989).

Markus and Kitayama (1991) argue that culture influences the people’s perceptions of themselves, others and the relationship of self with others. For instance, people from individualist cultures tend to attach greater importance to personal agendas and individual autonomy over the welfare of collectivity and their interdependence with their social unit (Hofstede, 1980; Schwartz, 1999). In collectivist cultures, people tend to put group welfare ahead of individual interests, and their sense of self is largely shaped by their embeddedness in the collectivity (Hofstede, 1980; Markus and Kitayama, 1991; Schwartz, 1999). As result of exposure to views and assumptions specific to a national culture and different means of socialization, people belonging to collectivist and individualist cultures may develop collectivist and individualist values respectively as distinct patterns of psychological tendencies (Markus and Kitayama, 1994; Triandis, 1989). Triandis (1989) argues that the values that reflect individualist orientation, i.e. personal autonomy and welfare, tend to characterize people from individualist cultures, while the values that reflect pro-social behaviour, such as emphasizing a group purpose, are likely to be associated with individuals belonging to nations that predominantly espouse collectivist values.

From a leadership perspective, values which leaders judge as personally important are partly shaped by the predominant values in the national society, and tend to act as an inner locus of control on choice and display of culturally correspondent behaviours (e.g. Kanungo and Jaeger, 1990; Kanungo et al., 1999). In fact, as a result of socialization to a different set of cultural values, managers assimilate social meanings and assumptions into their individual values (Van Maanen and Laurent, 1993) and carry this influence into their leadership roles and responsibilities (e.g. Geletkanycz, 1997; Schneider and DeMeyer, 1991; Shane, 1995; Van Maanen and Laurent, 1993).

The foregoing discussion lends credence to Hofstede’s (1980, 1983) argument that cultural values serve as mental programmes for all societal members and the influence of this programming reaches every individual through means of socialization. This brings about deep social patterning of managers’ personal values as these values in their development are deeply influenced by national culture (England, 1975). Thus, managers native to a national culture do not simply extract legitimacy from the cultural environment, rather culture deeply interpenetrates in their individual values (e.g. Kanungo and Jaeger, 1990). That is why their actions and decisions are largely constructed by the same value system that determines reactions of the target subordinates. In the light of foregoing discussion, we propose the following:

list-item.p: P1: The influence of leader personal values will produce correspondence between leadership styles and cultural values.

sec.title: Follower values and leadership cultural adaptation: An experiential learning perspective
sec.p: Feather (1992: 109) has proposed that ‘values are abstract structures that involve the beliefs that people hold about desirable ways of behaving or about desirable end states’. Values influence people’s perceptions and interpretation of different situations, which resultantly makes certain objects, events or activities and probable outcomes attractive for observers, while certain others are less attractive or even aversive (Feather, 1990, 1992). Based on this definition of values, it is expected that an employee’s construal of leadership behaviours and management practices as attractive or aversive may in part depend on his/her values. However, individuals hold different values and give prominence to certain values over others, which actually influence an individual’s interpretation of a situation and lead them to act in a value-consistent way (Verplanken and Holland, 2002). Managerial and motivational practices may be differently viewed as negatively or positively valent by followers holding different sets of values. For example, people holding self-enhancement values will positively evaluate managerial practices that provide opportunities for individual accomplishments. People driven by self-transcendent values, on the other hand, will experience enhancement when certain leader behaviours promote collective welfare and success. Importance of these two values to varying degrees for different employees makes it possible to predict follower reactions to different leadership behaviours (e.g. Fu et al., 2010). Logically, it may be expected that subordinates who hold a high level of self-enhancement values will react negatively to leaders who contribute to collective goals.

A number of prior studies show strong evidence for the notion that values play an important role in shaping organizational members’ reactions to different events they encounter at their workplace. As evidenced by many empirical works, values have been found to be related to organizational commitment (Glazer et al., 2004), self-efficacy and high performance (Earley, 1994), job involvement (Brockner et al., 1988), prosocial behaviour (McNeely and Meglino, 1994) and cooperation (Wanger, 1995). The findings from Jung and Avolio’s (2000) study showed that individual values mediated the effects of transactional and transformational leadership on performance. Probst and Lawler (2006) in their study found that cultural values of employees moderated their reactions to organizational announcements of downsizing and employee layoff.

Values can be used as a powerful lens for predicting employee reactions to leadership and management practices and developing behaviours that are closely adapted to employee values. However, for such adaptation there should be some value commonality across individual organizational members. In the absence of such commonality, each organizational member’s reactions would have to be understood independently and an adaptation to values would mean adaptation of leader behaviours to individual organizational members (Lines, 2006). National culture, being a community of values for its members, serves as a strong homologizer of individual values. As noted earlier, the work of Hofstede (1980) suggests four dimensions of national culture along which members of a particular society show substantial commonality in their values. Empirical research strongly supports that reactions of organizational members to management initiatives and practices differ across national cultures in ways predicted by differences in cultural values (Kirkman and Shapiro, 1997; Probst and Lawler, 2006). Practically speaking, then, in order to enhance acceptance or reduce resistance to various managerial approaches in different cultural settings, managers should develop knowledge of those potential sources that may relate to followers’ acceptance or resistance to certain leadership behaviours (Kirkman and Shapiro, 1997). This suggests that managers not only need to observe how subordinates react but also discover the underlying sources of followers’ reactions. Clearly, followers’ values are not inscribed on their faces, however, given time, managers as ardent observers may learn the true values that followers hold.

Traditional concepts of leadership have focused on how leaders create value mediated by one-way processes by which followers are influenced to work differently or harder in the pursuit of organizational goals. For example, transactional leaders influence followers by offering rewards in exchange for performance driving behaviours. Transformational leaders exert influence on followers by providing a compelling vision of the future along with a new set of values, presumably seen as attractive also for followers, leading to the enactment of behaviours in the pursuit of leaders’ visions and values (Bass and Riggio, 2006). We argue that these concepts do not sufficiently allow for an active role played by followers in the leader–follower relationship. Rather than presenting followers as passive stimulus-response puppets, we argue that follower characteristics represented by their value systems make up an important facet of the context in which leadership behaviours are enacted (Rubin et al., 2005). Moreover, the effectiveness of a particular leadership behaviour is highly dependent on how it is viewed by followers using values as criteria for assessing its appropriateness. Hence, we see leaders’ learning about and adaptation to followers’ values as crucial processes underlying effective leadership.

ELT (Kolb, 1984) offers a theoretical framework that could immensely help our understanding of how managers learn followers’ values and use that knowledge as a foundation to make behavioural adjustments. ELT defines learning as ‘the process whereby knowledge results from the combination of grasping and transforming experience’ (Kolb, 1984: 41). The theory suggests a learning cycle comprising four learning modes through which experiences can be grasped and transformed, resulting in creation of new knowledge. ELT juxtaposes concrete experience and abstract conceptualization as learning approaches to grasp experience and posits that experience may be transformed through learning modes of reflective observation and active experimentation (Kolb, 1984). People engaged in learning tend to develop four basic learning styles, i.e. diverging, assimilating, converging, and accommodating (Joy and Kolb, 2009; Kolb and Kolb, 2005), but in an idealized learning loop, they may touch all the modes in the learning cycle. That is, they create knowledge through being involved in an experience of tangible reality which provides a basis for reflections. By integrating and distilling those reflections, ideas and abstract concepts are developed which may serve as potential implications for further actions and decisions, and upon putting them into use they may lead to creation of new experiences.

While managing employees in organizations, managers may frequently get involved in concrete experiences, may engage in reflecting on those experiences, analyse them logically and develop abstract concepts that may serve as guiding maps to adopt different patterns of behaviour for employees holding different cultural values. We suggest that the underlying mechanism for this correspondence is a learning process by which leaders experiment with different leadership behaviours, and based on the observation of follower responses, they gradually develop implicit theories (Kolb, 1984) of followers’ value systems. Subsequently, leaders are likely to develop behavioural alternatives presumed to be consistent with the content of these value systems, enact these behaviours and observe follower responses anew. The leaders’ experiential learning may gradually lead to more accurate mental models of the underlying value systems of followers and tend to produce correspondence between leadership styles and follower cultural values.
Consequently we suggest the following proposition:

list-item.p: P2: The influence of follower values will produce correspondence between leadership styles and cultural values.

sec.title: Societal values and leadership cultural adaptation: An institutional perspective
sec.p: Organizations have to conform to normative, cognitive and regulatory domains of a country’s institutional environment to seek legitimacy from the society in which they operate (Scott, 1995). The normative domain constitutes cultural values which, as argued by Schwartz (1999), are reflected in social norms that specify acceptable forms of behaviour in different situations. The cognitive domain describes the development of shared schemas and common patterns of thinking in a particular culture, which people use without a conscious awareness to respond to and interpret situations they encounter. The regulatory domain pertains to the process of governing and regulating individual and organizational practices through various social institutions, such as regulatory bodies, courts and professional societies, etc. The normative pillar has the capacity to influence both cognitive and regulatory elements in a given cultural setting (Kostova and Zaheer, 1999), which is evident from the fact that shared schemas develop and activate as a result of cultural expectations (Erez and Earley, 1993; Lord and Maher, 1991); laws and regulations in a society portray social values and norms (Yukl, 2010); and the way societal institutions function and operate express cultural value priorities (Schwartz, 1999).

Organizations native to a national culture will be predicted to precociously conform to the various institutional pressures because of their largely unquestioned social validity. By virtue of this conformity, the domestic firms tend to possess values that may closely correspond to the societal values (Rhody and Tang, 1995) which may lead to specific behaviours within organizations in different national settings. For instance, Japanese firms are characterized by harmony, humanistic orientation, secured tenures, protection and nurturance by organizations, and loyalty and deference by employees, which are prototypical of Japanese social values (Burton, 1989). Possibly, legitimacy accrued from culture as a result of conformity to the larger societal values is the major factor that makes Japanese business firms thrive. American companies are characterized by a different set of value orientations compared to their Japanese counterparts (Ueno and Sekaran, 1992), but they carry out their business activities equally well in their respective cultural setting, which may be attributed to the congruence of their goals with the larger societal values (Parsons, 1960).

By comparison, a non-resident organization consciously and strategically chooses to comply with the societal values and norms of acceptable behaviour in anticipation of legitimacy and a variety of other benefits, such as increased prestige, stability and social support (DiMaggio, 1988; Meyer and Rowan, 1983). The organization’s compliance may earn it societal approval which in turn is likely to facilitate the organization in establishing legitimacy, enhance stability and pave the way to carry out its activities with a sustained logic of confidence (Meyer and Rowan, 1983). Compliance may also help produce a positive impression and evaluation of the organization’s procedures and processes that tends to reduce any chances that the organization’s operations, services or products will be negatively assessed by public and other stakeholders (Meyer and Scott, 1983). For example, an organization may enhance its legitimacy and avoid any likely public condemnation or fiscal penalty by fulfilling a government condition or mandate that reflects wider societal expectations (Oliver, 1991).

Institutional pressures, hence, greatly influence organizational structures and processes; it is the degree of the appropriate adaptation of various organizational and management practices to the prevailing cultural values that may determine the potential effectiveness of such practices (Newman and Nollen, 1996). The firms which do not comply with institutional pressures in a particular host culture may encounter problems of raising their outcome levels as a result of decreased cultural support. Stakeholders, i.e. consumers, in other cultural settings may perceive the functioning of foreign firms through the lens of their own culture (Harris and Moran, 1987), and expect organizations of foreign origin to comply behaviour acceptable in the wider society.

In summary, societal values influence courses of action and appropriate behaviours, which may also encompass organizational practices and processes, including individual-level behaviour in organizations, such as the way managerial leaders exhibit different behaviours (Currie et al., 2009; Spony, 2003). Since a distinct set of values characterize each national culture (Chakraborty, 1991), organized social activity (Biggart and Hamilton, 1987) is expected to be rooted in societal values. The capacity of these values to direct the conduct of organizational leaders, therefore, cannot be denied. Leaders may be exposed to social pressures and expectations in their cultural environment and this influence may also reach them through interaction of societal values with the organizational phenomenon (Currie et al., 2009). These institutional demands and expectations may influence leaders by acting as a source of guidance, information or pressure to make adjustments in their behaviours to fit them to the broader societal values (Currie et al., 2009). We propose the following:

list-item.p: P3: Societal values will influence managers to produce culturally correspondent leadership styles.

sec.title: Cultural value differences and strength of proposed mechanisms
sec.p: The mechanisms by which leaders’ individual, subordinate and societal values influence leadership styles are likely to be more or less effectual under different cultural settings. We next discuss how the vigour of each of the mechanisms is likely to be influenced when a particular cultural value is high or low in a cultural setting where leadership is enacted.

sec.title: Influence of leaders’ individual values and moderation by cultural setting
Collectivism versus individualism
sec.p: In collectivist cultures, people identify themselves as members of the larger social group and believe in promoting the group purpose over individual ideas and interests (Hofstede, 1980; Schwartz, 1999). People in such cultures tend to engage in cooperative behaviour and seek accomplishment of collective goals (Hofstede, 1980). Members of collectivist societies, being concerned about their social alienation, exhibit high behavioural conformity to the codes of behaviour established by the collectivity (Doney et al., 1998). Conversely, in individualistic cultures, the individual is considered to be an autonomous and unique entity who tends to prefer personal ideas, individual welfare and independence over group perspective, purpose or interests (Schwartz, 1999; Triandis et al., 1988). People in individualistic cultures consider social relationships as contractual and put greater emphasis on attaining self-serving goals (Earley, 1989; Singh, 1990) than acting in unison to achieve collective interests (Hofstede, 1980). Thus, managers belonging to a collectivist culture might experience more social reinforcement pressures than their counterparts from individualistic cultures. The pressure of social obligations may induce managers from collectivist societies to show low behavioural invariability to the societal norms and values (Ueno and Sekaran, 1992), which may closely align their personal values with the values characteristic of their national society (Van Maanen and Laurent, 1993). Thus, in collectivist cultures there are more chances that managers may internalize dominant societal values, and as a result their personal values and societal values may become highly congruent.

sec.title: Power distance (PD)
sec.p: In high PD societies, inequalities between people are widely accepted and hierarchies exist in all social structures that signify distance of power (Hofstede, 1980, 1984). The existence of hierarchies in the family system (e.g. between older and younger members), in education systems (between teachers and students) and in informal and formal organizations (between subordinates and superiors) indicate large power differences and inequalities between people. The people who are located at lower hierarchical levels are supposed to subjugate their own ideas and opinions to those of the people who are incumbents of the upper echelons in the hierarchical structure. For instance, in such cultures children, students and subordinates are generally expected to show obedience to parents, teachers and superiors respectively (e.g. Hofstede, 1984, 2001; Ralston et al., 1997), and expressing any candid differences of opinion are considered as tantamount to disrespect. Contrarily, in low power distance societies inequalities among members are not emphasized as there is less acceptance of vertical structures. Because hierarchies are less valued in such societies, people tend to recognize each other as moral equals (Booysen, 2001; Sagiv and Schwartz, 2007; Yan and Hunt, 2005). People, having equal rights, are not constrained to act in certain ways. This suggests that managers in high power distance cultures often correspond in their own values with those of relevant others in all walks of life, which in turn brings their personal preferences closer to what is preferred and valued in the larger society.

sec.title: Uncertainty avoidance (UA)
sec.p: In high UA cultures, tested patterns of behaviour are regarded as sacrosanct, and with the passage of time take on a rule-like status; abiding by them ensures certainty in social life. In such cultures, deviation from traditional rules and norms is intolerable and people have a strong tendency to stick to the widely accepted modes of behaviour (House et al., 2004; Yan and Hunt, 2005). Conversely, in low UA cultures, unique patterns of thinking are not considered a deviation from societal norms, and even new experiences that challenge traditional ways of thinking are endorsed and encouraged. A high UA culture is thus called a tight culture for its emphasis on conformity to group and social norms, and a low UA culture that allows more latitude in behaviour is called a loose culture (Hofstede, 1984). This suggests that personal-level values, in low UA societies, may keep their uniqueness considerably intact during various social interactions, while personal values in high UA cultures are subject to continuous social patterning that may render them congruent with the societal values in the long run.

sec.title: Masculinity versus femininity
sec.p: In masculine societies, people attach high importance to ambition, competition and success, and in their quest for achieving material success, members of such cultures adopt assertive behaviours (Hofstede, 1980; Hofstede and Arrindell, 1998). Being highly recognition and achievement oriented, people in masculine cultures are little concerned about cooperation and moral obligations, and they tend to be confrontational in social relationships (Doney et al., 1998). In contrast, people of feminine cultures value affiliation and nurturing relationships over personal success and advancement (Newman and Nollen, 1996), and they tend to respect the opinions and emotions of others. This suggests that people in masculine societies are likely to mainly act in accordance with their personal value system for their emphasis on personal achievement over social preferences. On the other hand, for members of feminine societies, personal prosperity is not the only stake in their life. Rather, they exhibit behaviours which nurture amicable relationships and provide space for others’ concerns and preferences (Doney et al., 1998). Personal value systems of leaders in feminine cultures are likely to become more congruent with the larger societal values.

sec.title: Paternalism
sec.p: In paternalistic cultures such as Japan, China, India, Turkey and Pakistan, the family system is based on patriarchal relationships between older and younger members of the family (Aycan et al., 2000; Kim, 1994; Pellegrini and Scandura, 2008). In such societies, the role of parents and elders is to protect the welfare of younger members of the family, and to guide and discipline their activities, in addition to acting on their behalf in making decisions. In return for the caring and nurturing behaviours of their elders, younger members of the family are expected to be respectful and loyal in their relationships with parents and elders. Since the relations are trust-driven and emotionally loaded, decisions of parents/elders are received warmly by the younger family members. In such societies, patriarchal bonding also permeates into the fabric of social and organizational life (Kim, 1994; Redding and Hsiao, 1995). In low paternalistic cultures, where the emphasis is on private self and individual autonomy, parents and elders have no strong inclination towards guiding and caring behaviours in their relationships with younger members of the family, and the younger members in return do not respond with loyalty and deference. Personal values of managers born and raised in paternalistic cultures are likely to reflect a strong moulding effect of the societal culture.

list-item.p: P4: Leaders’ personal values may produce correspondence between leadership styles and cultural values via a value internalization process, such that the relationship is likely to be stronger when a culture is high on collectivist, power distance, uncertainty avoidance, femininity and paternalistic values.

sec.title: Influence of followers’ values and moderation by cultural setting
Collectivism versus individualism
sec.p: Within collectivist cultures, the perceptions of in-group and out-group differences are stronger, and people seek to interact and align themselves with the group with which they share their identity and values (Dalton and Chrobot-Mason, 2007). Followers from collectivist cultures thus tend to positively evaluate leadership behaviours based on their cultural similarity, and behaviours that may appear dissimilar to the collective values are unlikely to be favourably received. In individualistic societies, people put greater priority on self-interest (Hofstede, 1980; Triandis et al., 1988), and they may not interact and align themselves only to the people with whom they share values because their social relationships tend to be deliberate and calculated (Gelfand et al., 2004). In these societies, reactions to leadership behaviours are likely to be primarily induced by followers’ motives of self-interest rather than congruence of leader values/behaviours with their shared values. This implies that, for leaders’ culturally non-adapted behaviours, value-based communities are predicted to develop more frequently among employees of high collectivist societies, revealing their values to leaders through negative responses.

sec.title: Power distance (PD)
sec.p: In high PD cultures, the status of leaders in organizations is legitimized (Schwartz, 1999) and in view of the perceived legitimacy linked to leadership positions, it is expected that followers will accept managerial actions even in the absence of perceived value congruence. Employees of such cultures are not strongly concerned about their own emotional dissonance in interaction with their superiors, and instead, display an unquestioning compliance (Chen et al., 2008). On the other hand, employees from low PD cultures participate in decision-making and have access to information which enables them to predict the likely consequences of various managerial actions. Compared to followers of PD cultures, they do not value a leader’s traditional orientation, rather logic and reason serve as the major standards for leader appraisal (Yan and Hunt, 2005). They are little concerned about formality and are expected to bypass their superiors in work-related matters (Adler, 1997). This suggests that follower reactions to various managerial actions and behaviours will be more visible in low PD societies than in high PD cultures.

sec.title: Uncertainty avoidance (UA)
sec.p: Employees in high UA cultures fear uncertainty and ambiguity and may have a preference for a predictable environment, while followers from low UA cultures may place greater emphasis on task variety and innovation at their workplace (Hofstede, 1980). Compared to their counterparts from high UA cultures, followers of low UA values tend to be tolerant of work-related ambiguities and change, and they are not shy of taking risks (Joy and Kolb, 2009; Offermann and Hellmann, 1997). In UA avoidance cultures, followers may not be tolerant of leader behaviours that are inconsistent with extant norms and values because they suspect such behaviours are a threat to their perceived job security and status. On the other hand, employees with low UA values are less resistant to ambiguity (Joy and Kolb, 2009), and they may be comfortable with leader behaviours not specific to the dominant values. This suggests that followers high on UA will react against novel behaviour, while followers with low UA values may be receptive to such behaviours for their emphasis on newness and change.

sec.title: Masculinity versus femininity
sec.p: Followers of masculine cultures seek conditions that enhance opportunities for personal recognition, rewards and advancement at the workplace (e.g. Triandis, 1994). They tend to attach importance to managerial behaviours and approaches that may promote such opportunities. In cultures dominated by feminine values, followers may greatly emphasize good working conditions and interpersonal relationships (Hofstede, 1980, 1984). They tend to build cordial relations and avoid behaviours that lead to confrontational situations with others. Thus, followers of masculine cultures may readily and strongly react against leader behaviours that hinder material success and do not foster a competitive and ambitious environment. Conversely, followers in feminine cultures may not react strongly and hastily to deviant managerial behaviour due to followers’ conciliatory, accommodative and relationship-fostering dispositions.

sec.title: Paternalism
sec.p: In high paternalistic cultures, leaders in organizations tend to provide support, guidance and protection to their subordinates (Aycan et al., 2000). In return for such caring and protective behaviours, subordinates owe loyalty, deference, and compliance to their superiors (Pellegrini and Scandura, 2006). Leaders in such societies are regarded as being more knowledgeable and able to assume the responsibility of providing guidance and making decisions for their subordinates. Contrarily, in low paternalistic cultures, followers tend to be cautious about separation of official and private life. They evaluate managers on the basis of how they perform in their official life rather than making appraisals based on managers’ personal interest in followers’ off-the-job activities. Followers in cultures low on paternalism are predicted to be more vocal and explicit in their reactions to deviant managerial behaviours, while in high paternalistic cultures, managerial behaviours incongruent with paternalism are not likely to elicit sudden and strong reactions from followers because of the parenthood associated with leadership positions.

list-item.p: P5: Followers’ values may produce correspondence between leadership styles and cultural values via a process of leader-based experiential learning, such that the relationship is likely to be stronger when a culture is high on collectivist, uncertainty avoidance and masculinity and low on power distance and paternalistic values.

sec.title: Influence of societal values and moderation by cultural setting
Collectivism versus individualism
sec.p: In collectivist cultures, social values, norms and rituals play an important role in supporting behavioural congruence and sanctioning inappropriate behaviour (Doney et al., 1998). Thus, to better understand a collectivist culture one not only needs to know the regulatory domain of a country but also correctly interpret the deep and complex structures of the cognitive and normative institutional elements. As argued by Kostova and Zaheer (1999), the cognitive and normative domains are harder to observe, understand and interpret correctly than the regulatory domain of a country’s institutional environment, foreign subsidiaries may be at a disadvantage in establishing legitimacy in the host culture until they correctly explore and interpret the complex web of cognitive and normative institutional elements. For instance, Cargill, a famous multinational company, could not thrive in the Indian market and finally had to retreat, not due to regulatory requirements but for paying negligible heed to the Indian norms and values (Kostova and Zaheer, 1999). On the other hand, in individualistic societies there is great tolerance for distinctive behaviours and variance in behaviour is not curbed (Doney et al., 1998). The desire for autonomy rooted in freedom and independence may lead to the poor development and perpetuation of socially accepted norms and traditions, hence social behaviour is likely to be mainly regulated and determined by laws and legal enactments. This suggests that societal values in collectivist cultures will put greater demands on organizations to closely adapt their practices to the host culture to establish and maintain legitimacy.

sec.title: Power distance (PD)
sec.p: High PD societies support adherence to established standards in social interactions. The wielding of influence and getting dominance over others being socially legitimized behaviours, organizations in high PD cultures tend to fall into either a dominant or dependent category compared to other specific organizations (Dickson et al., 2004). The dominant organizations dictate to organizations dependent on them and the latter have to comply with such mandates even if there are policy differences. On the other hand, in low PD societies organizations may get social approbation for the quality of their products and services because, as argued by Yan and Hunt (2005), people in countries with low PD values tend to make evaluations based on logic and reason. Stakeholders in such societies may logically evaluate organizational operations and activities instead of making assessments based on organizational structures, or the way organizations interact with other social entities. In their pursuit of societal approbation and/or avoiding any likely punishment, organizations operating in high PD cultures are likely to experience stringent coercive and regulatory pressures to adapt organizational practices and processes, including leadership behaviours, to the host culture.

sec.title: Uncertainty avoidance (UA)
sec.p: To establish public legitimacy, organizations operating in a national setting need to observe, understand and interpret correctly the normative, cognitive and regulatory institutional elements (Kostova and Zaheer, 1999). Because of the greater emphasis on clarity by high UA cultures (House et al., 2004), the institutional elements in such societies are expected to be explicit and clearly formalized in rules, laws, customs and traditions and are likely to be easy to observe, understand and interpret correctly by foreign observers. Legitimacy in such societies stems from making an organization’s goals and activities congruent with norms and values of the national society (Meyer and Scott, 1983; Parsons, 1960), organizations will make greater efforts to correctly understand the institutional elements in their environment to become isomorphic with other organizations. Conversely, low UA cultures being tolerant of innovative and entrepreneurial behaviours (Joy and Kolb, 2009), organizations may face less forceful institutional pressures to become isomorphic to achieve social legitimacy. This implies that societal values in high uncertainty avoidance cultures will exert a stronger influence on organizations to adapt their management practices to the values of host national culture.

sec.title: Masculinity versus femininity
sec.p: In masculine cultures, excelling and achievement oriented behaviours are strongly supported and valued (Kale and Barnes, 1992). That is why organizations in such societies tend to become growth and performance driven enterprises (e.g. Yan and Hunt, 2005). The primary focus of organizations on high material success place them in a situation of fierce competition, and organizations, whose strategies and goals are not geared towards high economic gains may find their survival at risk. Compared to organizations in masculine societies, organizations operating in feminine cultures emphasize the quality of interpersonal relations and quality of working life issues (Newman and Nollen, 1996). For such organizations, supporting people and society through benevolent and nurturing practices tend to be of paramount importance (Hofstede, 1984). Organizations in feminine cultures, being not solely driven by the agendas of economic growth, may carry out their operations in a considerably less competitive environment. This suggests that institutional pressures, i.e. coercive and mimetic pressures, are likely to be more salient and forceful in masculine societies than in cultures high on feminine values, which may result in stricter compliance with organizational behaviour in masculinity dominated cultures.

sec.title: Paternalism
sec.p: People in paternalistic societies prefer to be associated with organizations that promote workers’ welfare, and possess an environment where employees experience patriarchal relationships in their off-the-job lives (Pasa et al., 2001). Societal laws in such cultures influence organizations to adopt management practices that reflect paternalistic characteristics (Martinez and Dorfman, 1998). For instance, in Turkey, when an employee loses his job, the employer pays a reasonable amount to its outgoing worker, keeping in view the probability of post-severance economic problems (Pellegrini and Scandura, 2008). In such societies, benevolent practices in organizations primarily develop in response to strong cultural support. Contrarily, lack of humane orientation in low paternalistic cultures renders social relationships contractual and transactional. In cultures with low humane (paternalistic) values, state structures might fill this gap by securing the social and economic needs of its people (House et al., 2004). Thus, organizations operating in high paternalistic cultures need to respond to cognitive, normative and regulatory elements, while in low paternalistic cultures the pressure may only emanate from the regulatory domain. This suggests that in high paternalistic cultures organizations may face multiple institutional pressures to adapt to the host culture to establish and maintain legitimacy. Based on this analysis we propose the following:

list-item.p: P6: Societal values may influence managers’ display of culturally correspondent leadership styles via a process of external regulation, such that the relationship is likely to be stronger when a culture is high on collectivist, power distance, uncertainty avoidance, masculinity and paternalistic values.

sec.p: The three proposed mechanisms can operate independently, but it is not unlikely that they closely interact with one another. The influence of mechanisms is likely to be parallel or they may interact with one another in a complex way. For example, high intensity influence exerted by societal values may strengthen influence produced by leader personal values, because leaders in such cultures tend to be in a permanent state of conforming to the modes of behaviour that have wider social acceptance, which may lead to increased social patterning of leader personal values. On the other hand, in a society where subordinate values are likely to exert greater influence on leadership adaptation, influence of leader personal values on adaptive behaviours may be less vigorous. The underlying rationale is that when follower reactions to leadership behaviours are evident, leaders may exert effort to learn the underlying values for those reactions. As a result, new information related to follower values is assimilated into leaders’ existing cognitive structures. When leaders frequently observe follower reactions, they tend to develop more accurate knowledge structures of follower values (see Payne et al., 1993). Development of refined cognitive elements of follower values may take leaders away from the use of pre-existing categories and beliefs for understanding a situation (e.g. follower reactions). Thus, leadership styles in such cultural settings are less likely to be produced by stored scripts for behaviour.

sec.title: National cultures and strength of mechanisms
sec.p: Our discussion so far explicates the way a single cultural dimension may influence the strength of proposed mechanisms, but to diagnose the vigour of each mechanism in a national setting the intensity of all cultural dimensions needs to be determined. This is for the reason that all national cultures embody multidimensional characteristics and each cultural dimension may be high, low or moderate in terms of its intensity (see Yan and Hunt, 2005). For instance, we earlier suggested that the influence of leader personal values on culturally adapted behaviours will be stronger in cultures high on collectivist, power distance, uncertainty avoidance, femininity and paternalistic values, but interestingly the value constellation of many national cultures may not fit exactly in the proposed order. There are only a few societies which typify all these characteristics, there are certain other cultures which are either high or low on majority of the above dimensions, or present a midway pattern by being high on some dimensions and low on certain others. For instance, Turkey shows consistently high ranking on Hofstede’s (1980) cultural dimensions, and as noted by Pellegrini and Scandura (2008), Turkish culture is also characterized by high paternalism. China, in addition to showing high paternalistic values (Kim, 1994), also ranks high on power distance and collectivism. Conversely, US ranks low on all of the cultural dimensions (Hofstede, 1980; Northouse, 1997). The intensity of influence enacted by leader personal values, subordinate values or societal values may range from very high to very low for a culture, depending upon whether cultural dimensions have parallel effects, neutralize or weaken the influence of other value dimensions as per our proposed pattern.

In Table 1, we present a map regarding the predicted strength of each potential mechanism in different cultures, which reflects the joint influence of cultural dimensions. For example, cultural setting 1 is typical of Turkish cultural values (collectivism, high PD, UA, femininity and paternalism), where influence of leader personal values is assumed to be very high, influence of follower values is predicted to be moderately low and influence of societal values is anticipated to be high. The main mechanism of influence on adaptation of leadership in a cultural scenario like that of Turkey is, therefore, assumed to be through leader personal values. Cultural setting 6 is a representation of US culture (individualism, low PD and UA, low femininity and low paternalism), where major influence on leadership adaptation is presumed to emanate from follower values. Scenario 20 represents Chinese culture (collectivism, high PD, low UA, low femininity and high paternalism) and the strength of both personal values and societal values on leadership cultural adaptation is anticipated to be moderately high, while the influence stemming from follower values is predicted to be moderately low, which implies that in China follower reactions would have a negligible role in leadership adaptation.

sec.title: Study limitations, directions for future research and practical implications
Study limitations and directions for future research
sec.p: Prior research on the link between cultural values and leadership styles has mainly focused on the culture and leadership interface without clearly spelling-out the mechanisms by which the cultural influence is enacted. This paper fills the existing gap in the culture–leadership relationship literature and forms a foundation for empirical research: first, by exploring the potential mechanisms which may lead to cultural adaptation of leadership styles; and secondly, by conceptualizing the moderating effects of cultural dimensions on the strength of each potential mechanism.

Although our study offers deep theoretical and practical insights on leadership cultural adaptation, nonetheless a number of factors may limit the generalizability of our model in a cross-cultural setting. First, the study mainly focuses on moderation by national culture from a unidimensional perspective, and does not develop clear propositions regarding the strength of each potential mechanism after conceptualizing the net effect of all cultural dimensions, which may limit future testability of the model. Another limitation of this study is that it offers a brief description of interaction between the proposed mechanisms that provides partial clarification as to which mechanism will actually have influence on leadership adaptation in a cultural setting. Furthermore, the study does not include any discussion on moderating effects of organizational-level and individual-level factors such as organizational culture and leader’s education and age on the relationship between cultural values and leader culturally adaptive behaviours.

To better understand the process of cultural adaptation of leadership behaviours, future research in the first place, may examine the potential contribution of each mechanism by investigating the effects of leaders’ personal values, subordinates’ values and societal values. Second, research might determine if each of the proposed mechanisms is equally active in every national culture irrespective of a specific culture’s value constellation, or the strength of each mechanism is enhanced or diminished when certain value dimensions are high or low in a cultural setting. Relatedly, it would be interesting to discover if each mechanism operates independently or may influence and, in turn, be influenced by other potential mechanisms. The need is then to explore if the intensity of a value system is associated with specific leadership styles and such leadership styles are in turn related to follower performance outcomes. It would be equally useful to understand the relation of different value dimensions in each value system to certain leadership styles and the way such leadership styles are related to leader effectiveness.

Third and finally, the moderating effects of organizational culture and leader’s education and age on the relationship between cultural values and leader culturally adaptive behaviours need to be examined. Research may determine if the national culture and culture of the domestic firms is characterized by the same value dimensions. Relatedly, it would be exciting to find out if non-resident companies tend to maintain the same values of their home cultures, or such organizations differ in their inclination or capability to adopt the cultural value system of the host country. It is further warranted to discover whether the strong organizational culture of a foreign subsidiary, characterized by the home national values, exerts a negative influence on the adoption of local cultural values. Future research may indicate whether local managers employed by ethnocentric organizations (organizations with values strongly rooted in the home country) are acculturated to the leadership behaviours preferred by such organizations, and whether such socialization weakens the congruence effects between national culture and their leadership styles.

The constructs in our proposed model can be measured using existing instruments and measurement approaches. For instance, leaders’ individual, follower and societal values can be assessed by asking participants to indicate which values are personally important to them, which values are strongly endorsed by most members of their respective group of followers and what is their perception about endorsement of a certain value by an average member of their national society (Fischer, 2006; Wan et al., 2007). To measure values at three different levels, the same value survey can be used. Internalization of cultural values may be assessed by asking respondents to rate each item on a certain value type with regards to its importance as a source of intrinsic motivation in one’s life. External regulation can be measured by eliciting participants’ perceptions of importance of a value dimension in terms of the associated societal rewards or punishment, and approval of a cultural group for valuing a certain cultural dimension (Chirkov et al., 2003). It is, however, important to note that this study has included paternalism as a separate cultural dimension, which has mainly been tested in eastern cultures (Redding et al., 1994) that concurrently possess high power distance values. Our theoretical model, therefore, needs to be carefully tested in cultural settings, where earlier research on cultural values lacks sufficient evidence regarding paternalism as an independent cultural dimension.

sec.title: Implications for managerial leaders
sec.p: Our discussion of leadership adaptability to the national culture has significant practical implications for managers. First and foremost, managers should recognize that the manner in which followers react to different managerial approaches is related to their cultural values. Managers should therefore develop sufficient knowledge of follower cultural values to gain important insights into why different leader behaviours garner diverse responses from subordinates. Managers enacting leadership and implementing human resource strategies may improve their effectiveness if they, as ardent observers, understand and interpret follower reactions and explore underlying values (Lines, 2006). Knowledge of follower values may be used for predicting reactions to changes in leadership behaviours and for developing strategies and approaches that may gain follower acceptance, and even turn out to be stimulating (Lines, 2006). One specific implication in this regard is that in cultures where subordinates are not likely to reveal their values through vehement reactions silence does not imply that such employees are satisfied with deviant leader behaviours. Their reactions may rather be implicit and deviant behaviours may have a negative impact on their performance. This may warrant leaders closely scrutinizing employee responses by determining which managerial strategies are likely to be better received and which might adversely impact such groups of employees.

Another practical recommendation for managers and organizations is that to achieve and establish legitimacy in a cultural setting, specifically in cultures where influence intensity springing from societal values is high, all institutional domains in a national environment need to be monitored to explore deep structures of cultural values. The effort may appear easy but is more challenging as normative and cognitive elements are less visible and less explicit than their regulatory counterparts (Kostova and Zaheer, 1999).

sec.title: Implications for recruitment and selection of leaders
sec.p: This study offers a number of implications for recruitment and selection of managers in different cultures. Our theoretical model and table can be used to find out which mechanism or mechanisms operate with greater or lesser influence in a specific culture. Once the relative strength of each potential mechanism is determined in a particular country, specific strategies regarding recruitment, selection and training of managers may be introduced and implemented. For instance, in a culture where influence of personal values is assumed to be low and the strength of societal values is not high either, i.e. cultural scenarios 5, 6, 10 and 11, individuals are likely to have different values than those of average people in the society. In such a cultural setting, at the time of recruiting and selecting managers, people need to be assessed for their values to see the degree of their compatibility with the cultural values of that country, in addition to making assessments for skills and competence. Conversely, in cultures with high influence strength of personal values and/or societal values, emphasis in selection should be on skills rather than on cultural values. Potential managers in such cultures are likely to have values closely aligned with those of the average person in society, or they may exhibit socially approved behaviours in the face of intense social pressures and expectations. Foreign companies operating in such countries should preferably recruit local managers rather than assigning many leadership positions to expatriate managers.

In cultures where high influence is likely to emanate from follower values, for selection as managers, people should be tested for cognitive and behavioural complexity because they are likely to be frequently involved in framing and reframing of behaviours in the face of subordinate reactions. Managers in such cultures need to be exposed to multi-frame leadership (Bolman and Deal, 1991) development programmes to enable them to see follower reactions through different lenses and integrate them into logically sound conceptualizations (Kolb, 1984).
